content.raw:
The manual tag isn't necessary per se. There's only one track in bloom and it's configured to pull the latest version of the default branch whenever a new release is made.
Which means that tagging in the source branch is not used by the release process. But it's a good thing to do in my opinion. A scenario where I think the tag would be useful: if we were running bloom on a commit that wasn't obviously the start of a new release (i.e. if we rev'd the development version to 0.0.3 as soon as we started the next development cycle then tagged an arbitrary stopping point) it would be pretty difficult to go back and see where the release was created from without comparing the source files in the bloom upstream tag with the source files at each commit in the default branch.
